commit_message:
Rename roles to use underscore

It appears that '-' is not valid in role names in collections per
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/developing_collections.html#roles-directory

Change-Id: Id472a75ed71170208acc7cfbc79f7ad18945ea67

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-10 14:44:19.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] Test remove Queue used in Qos

Change-Id: Ia9077fc20e4ca360819a2e368c8c1f9250e5a6d8
'}, {'created': '2019-10-11 11:11:25.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] Test remove Queue used in Qos

Change-Id: Ia9077fc20e4ca360819a2e368c8c1f9250e5a6d8
'}, {'created': '2019-10-11 15:34:34.000000000', 'message': 'Check referential violation when deleting Queue from OVSDB

If a Queue is still used in a QoS register in the OVSDB, it cannot
be deleted. With the current design, only one QoS rule is created in
the database and several Queues are assigned to it.

If something external to the OVS agent is handling the Queues and by
mistake a Queue is assigned to other QoS registers, this error should
be solved: the Queue is removed from the QoS registers and then deleted.

This problem is happening now in testing, where several QoS rules are
created at the same time in the OVSDB. This should not happen in a
production environment, where only one OVS agent must be running.

Closes-Bug: #1845176
Change-Id: Ia9077fc20e4ca360819a2e368c8c1f9250e5a6d8
'}, {'created': '2019-10-15 17:11:05.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Check referential violation when deleting Queue from OVSDB

I NEED TO CHANGE THIS DESCRIPTION!!

If a Queue is still used in a QoS register in the OVSDB, it cannot
be deleted. With the current design, only one QoS rule is created in
the database and several Queues are assigned to it.

If something external to the OVS agent is handling the Queues and by
mistake a Queue is assigned to other QoS registers, this error should
be solved: the Queue is removed from the QoS registers and then deleted.

This problem is happening now in testing, where several QoS rules are
created at the same time in the OVSDB. This should not happen in a
production environment, where only one OVS agent must be running.

Closes-Bug: #1845176
Change-Id: Ia9077fc20e4ca360819a2e368c8c1f9250e5a6d8
'}, {'created': '2019-10-16 07:44:55.000000000', 'message': 'Add OVS QoS driver cache for minimum bandwidth rules

1. Add OVS QoS driver cache
Added minimum bandwidth rules cache in the OVS QoS driver. If a new
port is detected in the integration bridge, managed by the OVS agent
driver, the QoS extension is applied (if configured).

If this new port does not have a QoS rule, by default the QoS
configuration is reset in this port. Because this port has no Queue
related, the call "QosOVSAgentDriver.delete_minimum_bandwidth" should
not execute the rule cleanup.

This QoS rule cache implementation per porti is currently used in the
OVS QoS driver for the DSCP and the bandwitdh limit rules.

2. If a Queue cannot be deleted, log the QoS registers using it
If a Queue is still used in a QoS register in the OVSDB, it cannot
be deleted. With the current design, only one QoS rule is created in
the database and several Queues are assigned to it.

If something external to the OVS agent is handling the Queues and by
mistake a Queue is assigned to other QoS registers, this error is now
logged before raising the exception.

Closes-Bug: #1845176
Change-Id: Ia9077fc20e4ca360819a2e368c8c1f9250e5a6d8

commit_message:
Add OVS QoS driver cache for minimum bandwidth rules

1. Add OVS QoS driver cache
Added minimum bandwidth rules cache in the OVS QoS driver. If a new
port is detected in the integration bridge, managed by the OVS agent
driver, the QoS extension is applied (if configured).

If this new port does not have a QoS rule, by default the QoS
configuration is reset in this port. Because this port has no Queue
related, the call "QosOVSAgentDriver.delete_minimum_bandwidth" should
not execute the rule cleanup.

This QoS rule cache implementation per porti is currently used in the
OVS QoS driver for the DSCP and the bandwitdh limit rules.

2. If a Queue cannot be deleted, log the QoS registers using it
If a Queue is still used in a QoS register in the OVSDB, it cannot
be deleted. With the current design, only one QoS rule is created in
the database and several Queues are assigned to it.

If something external to the OVS agent is handling the Queues and by
mistake a Queue is assigned to other QoS registers, this error is now
logged before raising the exception.

Closes-Bug: #1845176
Change-Id: Ia9077fc20e4ca360819a2e368c8c1f9250e5a6d8

commit_message:
Remove TripleO job from Neutron's check queue

This job can't run on python 3 and it's failing 100% since long time.
There is no point to run it like that now as it's only waste of infra
resources.
We will re-add this job to Neutron's check queue when it will be fixed.

Change-Id: I7833295398686aca3c37859dbe4c1c9d2aca1c55

commit_message:
[OVN] Enable neutron-ovn-tempest-ovs-release job

The previous patch changed DevStack to deploy the OVN driver from the
Neutron repository instead of the networking-ovn one.

This patch is now enabling tempest testing that code in the check and
gate pipeline.

Change-Id: I772c33789443f08e4b70d37602a73d28fdf2f6fb
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
s/assertItemsEqual/assertCountEqual/g

assertItemsEqual was renamed to assertCountEqual in Python 3, and the
testsuite is failing now - rename it.
See also https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.assertCountEqual

This unbreaks the testsuite.

Change-Id: I910c7f2b3eae107a8d8022366f738b006cf4831a

commit_message:
Remove six usage

This repo does not support Python 2 anymore, so we don't need
six for compatibility between Python2 and 3, convert six usage to Python
3 code.

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/701743
Change-Id: I5f4d701a6cf3ad6d9684608820dc863c7b3fa12c

commit_message:
Allow multi-layer global environment/template directory

Current design only allow global environment files on first layer of
global environment path. This patch allow global environment files
exists in directory under global environment path.
Story: #1562577
Task: #17608

Change-Id: I6536224a3017c6b4a4ecef1b036e01190ecc5036

The origin way to include a yaml file in environment is to use the absolute path(*file:///A/B/C.yaml*), but it seems not that easy to maintain. I think we can replace with simple *get_file: C.yaml* and the resource registry will be much more clean
(from "AWS::CloudWatch::Alarm': file:///etc/heat/templates/AWS_CloudWatch_Alarm.yaml" 
to "AWS::CloudWatch::Alarm': get_file: AWS_CloudWatch_Alarm.yaml"
)

Also the environment direction might changed by config, so this patch make sure all file we use are exists inside environment directory.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2015-08-06 15:22:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

True enough I suppose, but IMO, not an overly burdensome task (from an operator's perspective), especially given that this is made even more trivial by configuration management. I wouldn't -2 this, but it doesn't seem necessary to me."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2015-08-10 00:00:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The existing heatclient template_utils should be used for resolving get_file instead of another implementation existing in the heat tree

https://github.com/openstack/python-heatclient/blob/master/heatclient/common/template_utils.py

(see line #72, but line #198 resolve_environment_urls might be the best entry point)'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2015-08-17 03:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I agree that we could just do without this.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-08-17 14:08:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I agree that we could just do without this.

I think maybe folks are missing the point of my original bug report a bit.

The point isn't that you have to use file://blah/foo.yaml in the resource_registry, it's that it's impossible to use get_file from within foo.yaml, because nothing ever resolves it.

So, if for example you wanted to include a server configured via puppet, where get_file is used to reference a puppet manifest, in the global environment this is impossible, you're forced to inline everything, everywhere, which is inconvenient for anything except very trivial usage.

Obviously no such problem exists for user-provided environments, so it's a relatively major limitation for operator defined global environments.

I'm happy to agree this is a corner case, low priority, or even something we can say "won't fix" to, but lets ensure we're all clear on what we're refusing to fix first.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2015-08-17 14:12:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Randall Burt: Are you saying get_file: file:///tmp/foo.yaml will already read the local filesystem?  I thought I'd tried that but perhaps I'm mistaken."}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2015-08-17 14:16:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

@Steven no, I (and others it seems) have misunderstood what this was for/doing. Thanks to your clarification, I'll remove my -1. I'll +1 for now given that I agree that this seems to be a corner case and I'm not convinced yet that the proposed implementation works according to your clarification."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2015-08-18 04:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

I think my implementation miss lead folks a lot. I will update it to a correct implement ASAP.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2015-09-01 07:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-09-01 08:49:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

'}, {'created': '2015-09-01 07:34:07.000000000', 'message': 'add get_file in HOT templates from global environment

Add get_file to include local file resolution when resolving the global
environment. This make sure all HOT templates included from environment
registry can use get_file function normally.
This patch also ensure no file are included from outside of environment
directory in global environment files dictionary.
get_file will search global environment dircetion for file contents, if
key in get_file function can not be resolved by files.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I5878bc4ba95eebd900c4d9a578e76f7fa023b4f8
Closes-Bug: #1454401

get_file will search global environment directory for file contents,
if key in get_file function can not be resolved by files.
This patch also refactor to get better use of template_utils.
Closes-Bug: #1454401

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

python-searchlightsclient is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I37810f2e78523388a70cad0034f8d4d9e73e218b

[{'created': '2020-01-15 15:01:31.000000000', 'message': 'Bypass openvswitch update logic if expected packages are not present

The nuage integration uses a different package name for openvswitch,
breaking the update steps. This patch bypasses the update logic if the
expected packages are not present allowing nuage deployments to manage
the openvswitch package some other other way.

Closes-Bug: #1858640
Change-Id: I8c116aba50cc7f1cb7cd3fd32cf8aec868e074ec
(cherry picked from commit f907d061ba1d8cf6fbd15fc242b162c618a70154)
'}]
commit_message:
Bypass openvswitch update logic if expected packages are not present

The nuage integration uses a different package name for openvswitch,
breaking the update steps. This patch bypasses the update logic if the
expected packages are not present allowing nuage deployments to manage
the openvswitch package some other other way.

Closes-Bug: #1858640
Change-Id: I8c116aba50cc7f1cb7cd3fd32cf8aec868e074ec
(cherry picked from commit f907d061ba1d8cf6fbd15fc242b162c618a70154)

'}, {'created': '2018-04-06 06:23:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add option to run performance tasks with security disabled

It's noted that kernel fixes for security/meltdown
has affected performance atleast I/O. As we run deployments
in different environments it's good to add an option
which can adjust the security settings to test performance.

This patch adds a new variable "kernel_sec" which
defaults to "true". This can be set to "false" in
order to run performance tasks with disable security.

Change-Id: If6f0bc02db6932aa8f367e38cc82df85063eaf87
Related-Bug: #1757556

commit_message:
Add option to run performance tasks with security disabled

It's noted that kernel fixes for security/meltdown
has affected performance at least I/O. As we run deployments
in different environments it's good to add an option
which can adjust the security settings to test performance.

This patch adds a new variable "kernel_sec" which
defaults to "true". This can be set to "false" in
order to run performance tasks with disable security.

Also add molecule scenario to test security_disable tasks.

Change-Id: If6f0bc02db6932aa8f367e38cc82df85063eaf87
Related-Bug: #1757556

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-10 16:23:23.000000000', 'message': 'Mount /boot from the host within the nova-compute container

libguestfs expects to find /boot/vmlinuz-* for the running version of
the kernel. This check is duplicated in nova-compute when libguestfs has
failed to launch, providing a useful bread crumb for operators [1].

Obviously when this is called from within the nova-compute container in
the context of a TripleO deployment this can easily fail after a minor
update that has pulled in a newer container containing a newer kernel.
This check could also fail in the opposite case if the host kernel is
updated past the version present in the container.

This change works around this by simply passing /boot as read-only
through to the nova-compute container ensure libguestfs is able to
always find the correct version of vmlinuz.

This should also allow us to eventually drop the kernel RPM from the
nova-compute container that has been a constant source of maintenance
overhead in terms of CVEs etc.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/virt/disk/vfs/guestfs.py#L75-L97

Change-Id: Iadef8f3300bb1b5b995052c1a35a1becbfd5730c
(cherry picked from commit 9c5c36632d23a693a60e490b3046b07b126b9154)
(cherry picked from commit 02faf53ea8bb672060c7cfedbc093d5cff809307)
'}]
commit_message:
Mount /boot from the host within the nova-compute container

libguestfs expects to find /boot/vmlinuz-* for the running version of
the kernel. This check is duplicated in nova-compute when libguestfs has
failed to launch, providing a useful bread crumb for operators [1].

Obviously when this is called from within the nova-compute container in
the context of a TripleO deployment this can easily fail after a minor
update that has pulled in a newer container containing a newer kernel.
This check could also fail in the opposite case if the host kernel is
updated past the version present in the container.

This change works around this by simply passing /boot as read-only
through to the nova-compute container ensure libguestfs is able to
always find the correct version of vmlinuz.

This should also allow us to eventually drop the kernel RPM from the
nova-compute container that has been a constant source of maintenance
overhead in terms of CVEs etc.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/virt/disk/vfs/guestfs.py#L75-L97

Change-Id: Iadef8f3300bb1b5b995052c1a35a1becbfd5730c
(cherry picked from commit 9c5c36632d23a693a60e490b3046b07b126b9154)
(cherry picked from commit 02faf53ea8bb672060c7cfedbc093d5cff809307)

[OVN] Pass context while removing objects in OVN client

This context was required but not passed. This change adds it.

Change-Id: I5e5e14d5a621fc4a790810d15e1162f90898282e

commit_message:
Add 'scale-up' upgrade steps for manila

This patch adds the missing steps for 'scale-up' upgrade
support for the manila service similar to the implementation
in I3cfd4272449b207874723682903505d2bbdb435b

Related-Bug: #1838971
Depends-On: I2c468e608a8f70d031b9ba08521bb75f7094c048
Change-Id: I6deb1e2e76c1e471c1ff9b6b05dbde86eb00fbdf

commit_message:
Add short node name override support to manila

In line with the cinder & cinder-backup services, we add
short node name override support to manila when implemented
with pacemaker.

This is required in order to complete the 'scale-up' upgrade
steps for manila similar to the implementation in
I3cfd4272449b207874723682903505d2bbdb435b

Included is also an update to the tests and their fixtures to
ensure that the unit tests for the manila data are consistent
with the other similar services (cinder volume and cinder
backup).

Related-Bug: #1838971
Change-Id: I2c468e608a8f70d031b9ba08521bb75f7094c048
(cherry picked from commit e1348fecc80a5c746fd612d7c8a3cbbb58a974d4)

commit_message:
Add short node name override support to manila

In line with the cinder & cinder-backup services, we add
short node name override support to manila when implemented
with pacemaker.

This is required in order to complete the 'scale-up' upgrade
steps for manila similar to the implementation in
I3cfd4272449b207874723682903505d2bbdb435b

Included is also an update to the tests and their fixtures to
ensure that the unit tests for the manila data are consistent
with the other similar services (cinder volume and cinder
backup).

Related-Bug: #1838971
Change-Id: I2c468e608a8f70d031b9ba08521bb75f7094c048
(cherry picked from commit e1348fecc80a5c746fd612d7c8a3cbbb58a974d4)

So today ovs mechanism driver can bind Direct port see [1] for ovs offload.
ovs was extended with tc-offload to support rate limit see [1].
The ovs qos drive [2] it limited to work only with Normal Ports, so we
can't put QOS rules on direct port.
We just want to add Direct port to ovs Qos driver as done here [4]

[2] - https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/mech_driver/mech_openvswitch.py#L83

[4] - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/611605/

"}, {'created': '2019-11-17 13:21:19.000000000', 'message': "Add support for direct ports with QoS in OVS

Today OVS mechanism driver can bind Direct port see [1] for OVS hardware
offloads.
OVS was extended with tc-offload to support rate limit see [1].
The OVS QoS driver [2] is limited to work only with Normal Ports, so we
can't put QoS rules on direct port.
This patch proposes to add support in OVS QoS driver for direct ports.
The mechanism to enforce such policies is the same with normal and
hardware offloaded direct ports.

[1] - https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/e7f6ba220e10c0b560da097185514b6e33e2dc71
[2] - https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/mech_driver/mech_openvswitch.py#L83
[3] - https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/services/qos/drivers/openvswitch/driver.py#L56

Change-Id: I24b5cd6c022e479080fc84e4c445c9cddfc88e38

commit_message:
Add support for direct ports with QoS in OVS

Today OVS mechanism driver can bind Direct port see [1] for OVS hardware
offloads.
OVS was extended with tc-offload to support rate limit see [2].
The OVS QoS driver [3] is limited to work only with Normal Ports, so we
can't put QoS rules on direct port.
This patch proposes to add support in OVS QoS driver for direct ports.
The mechanism to enforce such policies is the same with normal and
hardware offloaded direct ports.

[1] - https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/e7f6ba220e10c0b560da097185514b6e33e2dc71
[2] - https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/3b074128ca91ba335bd8ef9db8dfe00fda51a63d/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/mech_driver/mech_openvswitch.py#L83
[3] - https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/3b074128ca91ba335bd8ef9db8dfe00fda51a63d/neutron/services/qos/drivers/openvswitch/driver.py#L56

Change-Id: I24b5cd6c022e479080fc84e4c445c9cddfc88e38
Closes-Bug: #1843165

commit_message:
Document OVNDBsVipPort for deployed-server

As OVNDBsVipPort was added a new top level VIP, it needs to mapped
appropriately as is done for Redis. This patch updates the documentation
to further cover what is needed and how to do the mappings and
DeployedServerPortMap values.

Change-Id: Ia3d053a107519b89f1644dd0b9ae9b6654bd78ee

run a ceph job on ocata but not pike so let's just
remove it. Since it's non-voting if it breaks no one
will likely notice anyway.

Change-Id: I3b088925dd46898bda6f74af4b933cfa732c31b7

commit_message:
ocata-only: drop non-voting ceph job

Nova on stable/ocata is the last remaining user of
legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-devstack-plugin-ceph and
runs it non-voting. stable/ocata is in extended
maintenance mode and doesn't see much action anymore.
Furthermore, the ceph job is being removed from nova
in stable/pike testing [1] so it'd be a bit weird to
run a ceph job on ocata but not pike so let's just
remove it. Since it's non-voting if it breaks no one
will likely notice anyway.

[1] I9e153f86c81ed6d9f8d9682b66d6d5c7f7b25296

Change-Id: I3b088925dd46898bda6f74af4b933cfa732c31b7

commit_message:
Make rsyslog file_input bulletproof

This patch makes rsyslog::file_input accept also $sources as single hash.
Currently when $sources is not array deployment fails.

Change-Id: I91d9f8ffb1e0c8bbdbc90696950aafd797ff380c
(cherry picked from commit 8c813bc8ac6b1541ce32a82bdc0992c16464acf4)

subject: Build reproducible wheels for our wheel cache
messages:
[{'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-20 20:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-01-20 20:26:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-21 16:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-01-21 17:26:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

From my RPM packaging background, I would set "-g0 -O2" since in most projects CFLAGS is the final value. Some add values they need to CFLAGS.

The problem I see is that projects use CFLAGS=-O2 and with setting -g0 we override the value and end with "-g0" and an implicit "-O0" - thus no optimization.

Can we test this before we deploy it?

Otherwise, let's merge and review the logs - both that we can compile all packages and that we don't end without optimization.

So, I'm fine with merging if needed for testing - but feel not confident enough to +2.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-21 22:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-21 23:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Okay, after further digging I found this anecdote:

"Some package install scripts, like SDL, allow CFLAGS settings to override their normal settings (instead of append to them), so setting CFLAGS can cause harm in this case." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CFLAGS

I'm also finding references to some random Makefiles accepting nonstandard envvars like XCFLAGS or ADD_CFLAGS as a workaround for appending to their generated CFLAGS lists. I agree this needs some more focused testing to determine the extent of any negative impact.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-20 20:21:33.000000000', 'message': "Build reproducible wheels for our wheel cache

Where possible, avoid common causes of variance between wheel builds
by setting a consistent file modification timestamp in ZIP archives
and disabling debug information in compiled C extensions. This
doesn't fix all reproducibility issues, but it does at least address
the ones which are not particularly under the control of the
maintainers of the software. Most other reproducibility issues
should be fixed upstream.

Change-Id: I138511865f104d17f60026b3f5de1144c13f565a
"}]
commit_message:
Build reproducible wheels for our wheel cache

Where possible, avoid common causes of variance between wheel builds
by setting a consistent file modification timestamp in ZIP archives
and disabling debug information in compiled C extensions. This
doesn't fix all reproducibility issues, but it does at least address
the ones which are not particularly under the control of the
maintainers of the software. Most other reproducibility issues
should be fixed upstream.

Change-Id: I138511865f104d17f60026b3f5de1144c13f565a

commit_message:
Add upgrade check for removed Veritas Access driver

The Veritas Access driver has been removed. This adds an upgrade check
to warn if it is still configured.

Change-Id: Ib8fc106e2f264908227794ac34d41e603bedf55a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

Tested this change here [1].  Ceph NFS job logs on ubuntu bionic [2] and CentOS 7 [3] have the desired ganesha config and log files; the corresponding CephFS native (ganesha not installed) logs [4] [5] do not.

[1]  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/626220/

[2] http://logs.openstack.org/20/626220/10/check/manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-cephfs-nfs/3882434/logs/

[3] http://logs.openstack.org/20/626220/10/check/manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-cephfs-nfs-centos-7/2c5a506/logs/

[4] http://logs.openstack.org/20/626220/10/check/manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-cephfs-native/e9b595a/logs/

[5] http://logs.openstack.org/20/626220/10/check/manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-cephfs-native-centos-7/a9c15af/logs/

The two experimental glusterfs-nfs jobs failed during stack.sh before ganesha packages were installed.'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2018-12-22 03:48:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Nice, thanks Tom!'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-01-22 11:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-01-22 14:22:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-07 22:27:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

bump

I think this is harmless to others and would be quite useful for manila.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-22 11:22:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Please note that the log in question, while vital information for debugging issues when ganesha is running, is only thirty or forty lines long.  No spam and fill up servers issues here.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-02-22 15:35:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Is this code even being used anywhere besides legacy jobs?'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-22 18:35:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Is this code even being used anywhere besides legacy jobs?

The manila cephfs with nfs job uses it. That job hasn't been converted to zuulv3 native yet but it's not "legacy" in any other sense.  This is the most viable software defined back end for manila where by "viable" I mean that it can scale out, not introduce a single point of failure in data path, etc.  It's a totally open source, production quality alternative to the proprietary back ends that traditionally manila users relied on.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-02-22 20:25:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I see. I got the impression we had basically frozen devstack-gate and were recommending jobs which needed different behavior move off of it rather than extend it, but I'll admit I've not been reviewing changes to it on any regular basis so may be mistaken there."}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-04-15 20:42:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Still useful/important to the manila team that plans to move its legacy jobs to Zuul v3 hopefully in the Train cycle..'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-07-18 03:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sigh. Can we please get this to merge :('}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-07-18 12:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-07-18 12:51:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Just a reminder, review bandwidth for devstack-gate is very low as it's been deprecated for a couple of years now in favor of the Ansible playbooks in the devstack repository. I strongly recommend redoing jobs which depend on the old devstack-gate framework at your earliest convenience."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-09-22 20:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-10-16 18:19:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-01-21 22:57:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}]

commit_message:
Capture nfs-ganesha logs and conf

If nfs-ganesha is used as an NFS gateway for another filesystem
like CephFS or glusterfs, then its configuration and logs are
critical for debugging service issues.

Capture these logs in the same manner that we capture logs and
configuration for ceph and gluster themselves.

Change-Id: I12875c7b979a60f46185ab33bae8ea4be0f759d9

commit_message:
Document the alembic CLI better in README

While we use ``cyborg-dbsync revision --message --autogenerate``
(Note in README) to upgrate the db script, it raises an error,
such as:

root@ubuntu:# cyborg-dbsync revision --message --autogenerate
usage: cyborg-dbsync revision [-h] [-m MESSAGE] [--autogenerate]
cyborg-dbsync revision: error: argument -m/--message: expected one
argument

So add a brief message after the "--message" parameter to make the
command run correctly.

Change-Id: I50cb8f105b309b1f7c7653bca2897d31841e0e46

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-17 20:26:37.000000000', 'message': "Exclude all device_ids that belong to Neutron DHCP Agent

It looks like sometimes, the device_id for ports created
by Neutron DHCP Agent can be in the form of:

- dhcp-$hostuuid-$networkid
- 'reserved_dhcp_port' (DEVICE_ID_RESERVED_DHCP_PORT)

Current code is only taking the first form into account when
skipping Neutron DHCP Agent ports. This patch is changing it
to include both forms.

Closes-Bug: #1848521
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)
"}]
commit_message:
Exclude all device_ids that belong to Neutron DHCP Agent

It looks like sometimes, the device_id for ports created
by Neutron DHCP Agent can be in the form of:

- dhcp-$hostuuid-$networkid
- 'reserved_dhcp_port' (DEVICE_ID_RESERVED_DHCP_PORT)

Current code is only taking the first form into account when
skipping Neutron DHCP Agent ports. This patch is changing it
to include both forms.

Closes-Bug: #1848521
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)

commit_message:
Exclude all device_ids that belong to Neutron DHCP Agent

It looks like sometimes, the device_id for ports created
by Neutron DHCP Agent can be in the form of:

- dhcp-$hostuuid-$networkid
- 'reserved_dhcp_port' (DEVICE_ID_RESERVED_DHCP_PORT)

Current code is only taking the first form into account when
skipping Neutron DHCP Agent ports. This patch is changing it
to include both forms.

Closes-Bug: #1848521
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)

Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)
"}]
commit_message:
Exclude all device_ids that belong to Neutron DHCP Agent

It looks like sometimes, the device_id for ports created
by Neutron DHCP Agent can be in the form of:

- dhcp-$hostuuid-$networkid
- 'reserved_dhcp_port' (DEVICE_ID_RESERVED_DHCP_PORT)

Current code is only taking the first form into account when
skipping Neutron DHCP Agent ports. This patch is changing it
to include both forms.

Closes-Bug: #1848521
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)

commit_message:
Return an error if tripleo-ansible deployed containers

For now, we assume that tripleo-ansible & paunch aren't playing well
together. So let's make sure that when containers were deployed with
tripleo-ansible, paunch CLI can't be used anymore.

Change-Id: I3f79a42da8798e24fad1a3ccc18efcc26e118c4d
(cherry picked from commit 3e19521fd47d39c6069399e42aad832a78ebcb78)

commit_message:
Normalize role names when generating roles

Roles can no longer have a "-" in them according to the upstream ansible
documentation[0]. This change ensures that we're no longer generating roles
that have a "-" within them. The role-addition.yml playbook will now
normalize the name and replace any "-" with an "_".

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/developing_collections.html#roles-directory

Change-Id: Ib758906a08dd611589394c77c627510d667034e9
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-14 15:26:29.000000000', 'message': "demarcate python-memcached requirements

To support Python3, we need python-memcached 1.58 or above. However,
projects such as keystonemiddleware[1] have python-memcached 1.56
in its lower-constraints.txt. For stable/stein, Python3 is now the
defult[2]. However, we generally avoid changing lower constraints in
the stable branches so we don't inadvertently break the downstream
consumers. Therefore, we need to separate python-memcached requirement
for the respective python versions.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/stable/stein/lower-constraints.txt#L61
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ifb805954ff36420004d552a690046d8ddf3bed5c
"}]
commit_message:
demarcate python-memcached requirements

To support Python3, we need python-memcached 1.58 or above. However,
projects such as keystonemiddleware[1] have python-memcached 1.56
in its lower-constraints.txt. For stable/stein, Python3 is now the
defult[2]. However, we generally avoid changing lower constraints in
the stable branches so we don't inadvertently break the downstream
consumers. Therefore, we need to separate python-memcached requirement
for the respective python versions.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/stable/stein/lower-constraints.txt#L61
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ifb805954ff36420004d552a690046d8ddf3bed5c

commit_message:
Add audit user to Mariadb

An audit user is added to Mariadb with only the SELECT permission
to mysql database user table for database user audit purposes.

Change-Id: I5d046dd263e0994fea66e69359931b7dba4a766c

commit_message:
roles: Remove use of NovaVcpuPinSet from ComputeRealTime

This has been deprecated and replaced by 'NovaComputeCpuDedicatedSet'
and 'NovaComputeCpuSharedSet', as seen in change
Ibba4273526392985ede6da2ef3fec66a61407777. Update the ComputeRealTime
role to reflect this.

Change-Id: I52c52b62f1c21214b98c98773c8647609cb81d52
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1860009
(cherry picked from commit d91a99af32d6ad4a72eedaf20b91bf0871ad62d8)

commit_message:
Remove six usage

This repo does not support Python 2 anymore, so we don't need
six for compatibility between Python2 and 3, convert six usage to Python
3 code.

Change-Id: Ife3910b1e66d2d8bc5dd5a5c56f7d5ef0b64ea01
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/701743

  with this API version.

* Rewrite of the driver to use the Datera Python-SDK instead of
  hand-rolled connections.  Usage requires the dfs_sdk python package
* Dropping support for default_storage_name and default_volume_name
  volume-type keys
* Added CHAP support
* Implemented fast-path Glance-->Datera image cloning with clone_image RPC
* Implemented fast-path volume retype

* Added iops_per_gb and bandwidth_per_gb volume-type keys
* Implemented update_migrated_volume
* Increased number of stats reported with get_volume_stats
* API fallback now only occurs during driver initialization.  This
  increases driver performance
* Added config option for customizing volume-type default values
* Implemented template size override
* Implemented LDAP support
* Added support for filter_functions and goodness_functions
* Changed version string to date-based
* Implemented manage_existing_snapshot and related RPCs

commit_message:
{WIP} Update in-tree Datera Cinder driver

* Dropping support for v2 API.  No Datera products exist in production
  with this API version.
* Added v2.2 API support
* Rewrite of the driver to use the Datera Python-SDK instead of
  hand-rolled connections.  Usage requires the dfs_sdk python package
* Dropping support for default_storage_name and default_volume_name
  volume-type keys
* Added CHAP support
* Implemented fast-path Glance-->Datera image cloning with clone_image RPC
* Implemented fast-path volume retype
* Rewrote unit tests from scratch
* Added iops_per_gb and bandwidth_per_gb volume-type keys
* Implemented update_migrated_volume
* Increased number of stats reported with get_volume_stats
* API fallback now only occurs during driver initialization.  This
  increases driver performance
* Added config option for customizing volume-type default values
* Implemented template size override
* Implemented LDAP support
* Added support for filter_functions and goodness_functions
* Changed version string to date-based
* Implemented manage_existing_snapshot and related RPCs

Change-Id: I15f96397a9e1238c0ed58a84148e0626d395277b

commit_message:
s/assertItemsEqual/assertCountEqual/g

assertItemsEqual was renamed to assertCountEqual in Python 3, and the
testsuite is failing now - rename it.
See also https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.assertCountEqual

This unbreaks the testsuite.

Change-Id: I54941245a4cc77494b7e2a969a996bab505fa2c8

commit_message:
Add docs for app cred access rules

We had documentation in the API reference but not in the user guide. Add
information about creating and managing access rules to the user guide
to make it more user-friendly.

Change-Id: Iaa66c8220e65083551daf727b52226da5cce5313
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/677857

[{'created': '2020-01-16 15:48:05.000000000', 'message': "Do not force remove containers

Paunch does docker/podman rm -f, when removes containers. It seems it
returns too early, having some leftovers (like docker service
endpoints) behind or pending for it to be removed later, in case of
big fat deamons.

Long story short, don't do rm -f and allow it to do its job gracefully
and without a hurry.

commit_message:
Do not force remove containers

Paunch does docker/podman rm -f, when removes containers. It seems it
returns too early, having some leftovers (like docker service
endpoints) behind or pending for it to be removed later, in case of
big fat deamons.

Long story short, don't do rm -f and allow it to do its job gracefully
and without a hurry.

Change-Id: I346c49cb204f273bd7077ca5153412cda9846534
Closes-Bug: #1860004
Co-authored-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Assign service role for ironic user

We expect service role is assigned to a user who use service
user token feature.

Currently ironic uses it to communicate with glance, so we
should assign the role to ironic user in keystone identity.

Change-Id: Ib6836a7593d165466be34c63a20463a3b7b817a8

In the devstack lib/neutron-legacy code, the Nova metadata
host address is un-quoted if it is IPv6, i.e. 2001:db8::1,
not [2001:db8::1].  We should be doing the same here.

Change-Id: Id2ac188a97e43f1996fee8db9a232d6035c62a82
'}]
commit_message:
Un-quote metadata address if it is IPv6

In the devstack lib/neutron-legacy code, the Nova metadata
host address is un-quoted if it is IPv6, i.e. 2001:db8::1,
not [2001:db8::1].  We should be doing the same here.

Change-Id: Id2ac188a97e43f1996fee8db9a232d6035c62a82

The reason bug #1860155 was triggered was because the kill script did
not have a stanza for handling the signal that was passed in, which is
signal 15.  Since signal 15 is unhandled, keepalived processes will

Related-bug: #1860155

commit_message:
Add handling of signal 15 in kill script

The reason bug #1860155 was triggered was because the kill script did
not have a stanza for handling the signal that was passed in, which is
signal 15.  Since signal 15 is unhandled, keepalived processes will
still stick around.  Add handling for signal 15.

Change-Id: I632a3ef5ec137df10f647335f6354589c2316fd0
Related-bug: #1860155

commit_message:
Fix functional tests for py3

Fix various things so the functional tests will work under python3:

- A hashlib.md5() can only be update()d with an encoded string in py3.
- There's no dict.iteritems(), change to dict.items() (which is already
  an iterator).
- Open temp files with 'w+' mode rather than the default 'w+b' (as an
  alternative to encoding all the write and expected-read payloads as
  bytes).
- (This is a weird one) Explicitly raise SkipTest from unittest (rather
  than unittest2, which is where cls.skipException landed). Not sure why
  this is busted, but this moves the ball.

Change-Id: Ic9b2b47848a600e87a3674289ae7ae8c3e091fee

commit_message:
Make tests pass in 2020

Without this patch, build failed after 2019-12-31 with
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/test_auth.py", line 226, in test_authenticate_success_password_unscoped
    self.assertRequestBodyIs(json=self.TEST_REQUEST_BODY)
  File "keystoneclient/tests/unit/utils.py", line 72, in assertRequestBodyIs
    self.assertEqual(json, val)

NOTE: in addition to the orginal backport, this patch adds the following
changes. The changes has to be combined into a single patch in order to
avoid circular dependencies.

1. fixed bandit complains in keystoneclient/common/cms.py. The literal 'sha256'
is the default hash algorithm, not a sensitive password. Marking it as false
positive so bandit can stop chirping.

2. combined with cherry pick from commit
f2d3fec9b254f9c47e97ddf48e3c5f7614b87f1b to avoid circular dependency. Without
combining them, neither backport will pass all the gates since pep8 has
switched over to use python3 now.

3. combined with cherry pick from commit
b29f478f28c4989156cfe87392cbd308e3f55c1e to avoid circular dependency. Without
combining them, neither backport will pass all the gates since bandit will
have a false positive on the hash algorithm.

Change-Id: I0e44d9896c5970f0ca07438c372aec826aeb5c77
(cherry picked from commit f2d3fec9b254f9c47e97ddf48e3c5f7614b87f1b)
(cherry picked from commit acc21ff06154e16de16583fe6994207d689ed054)
(cherry picked from commit b29f478f28c4989156cfe87392cbd308e3f55c1e)
(cherry picked from commit 9da2e0bdd83d481091814a8c6f40ab3ff39ffa9c)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-14 01:20:13.000000000', 'message': "demarcate python-memcached requirements

To support Python3, we need python-memcached 1.58 or above. However,
projects such as keystonemiddleware[1] have python-memcached 1.56
in its lower-constraints.txt. For stable/stein, Python3 is now the
defult[2]. However, we generally avoid changing lower constraints in
the stable branches so we don't inadvertently break the downstream
consumers. Therefore, we need to separate python-memcached requirement
for the respective python versions.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/stable/stein/lower-constraints.txt#L61
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ifb805954ff36420004d552a690046d8ddf3bed5c
"}]
commit_message:
demarcate python-memcached requirements

To support Python3, we need python-memcached 1.58 or above. However,
projects such as keystonemiddleware[1] have python-memcached 1.56
in its lower-constraints.txt. For stable/stein, Python3 is now the
defult[2]. However, we generally avoid changing lower constraints in
the stable branches so we don't inadvertently break the downstream
consumers. Therefore, we need to separate python-memcached requirement
for the respective python versions.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/stable/stein/lower-constraints.txt#L61
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Ifb805954ff36420004d552a690046d8ddf3bed5c

subject: [Follow Up] OVS DPDK port representors support
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 9732, 'name': 'Mellanox CI', 'email': 'mlnx-openstack-ci@dev.mellanox.co.il', 'username': 'mellanox', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 12171, 'name': 'Moshe Levi', 'email': 'moshele@nvidia.com', 'username': 'moshele'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25241, 'name': 'waleed mousa', 'email': 'waleedm@nvidia.com', 'username': 'waleedm'}, {'_account_id': 25733, 'name': 'Jan Gutter', 'email': 'github@jangutter.com', 'username': 'jangutter'}, {'_account_id': 28714, 'name': 'Adrian Chiris', 'email': 'adrianc@nvidia.com', 'username': 'adrianc'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 22948, 'date': '2019-06-18 12:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-18 12:34:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

this fundementally cannot work.

if the pf is bound to the kernel then libvirt can
and wil set the vf mac via the pf.

if the pf is bound to dpdk we cannot use ip tools to set the vf
mac via the kernel'}, {'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2019-06-18 12:42:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> this fundementally cannot work.
 > 
 > if the pf is bound to the kernel then libvirt can
 > and wil set the vf mac via the pf.
 > 
 > if the pf is bound to dpdk we cannot use ip tools to set the vf
 > mac via the kernel

What do you mean can't work? so if we do pci passthrough we will move the set of the mac address to the os-vif plug. so for bifurcated it will be done with ip link and for none bifurcated it will done with whatever they choose to do here. otherwise how the bifurcated will set the mac address"}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2019-06-18 12:54:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

TL;DR Summary:
This patch mixes kernel and DPDK interfaces: for it to be acceptable, the Nova project would likely have to push it. I'd be comfortable with this approach _only_ if broad acceptance has been achieved (likely with an approved spec).

Note to reviewers:
The os-vif object for VIFHostDevice maps to two libvirt primitives. Currently, Nova only understands os-vif objects that map to the element of the form <interface type='hostdev'>. This can be fixed, more reasons later on why it wasn't urgent.

When this interface type=hostdev element is used in libvirt, it's _libvirt_ code that manages the VF MAC lifecycle. Setting it before passthrough and clearing it afterwards. Currently the code in libvirt requires a netdev to manage the VF: it uses iproute2 ndo's to set the VF options before it gets passed through. This patch is not needed in that case.

The second method that libvirt can pass a network device through is by passing it as an untreated PCI device. In that case, it does NO config, and security depends on the VF being treated before and after the VM lifecycle. This corresponds to the libvirt <hostdev mode='subsystem' type='pci'> element. This method is prone to race conditions and generally used as a last resort.

The chief issue is that there is no cross-vendor method of treating a VF in this case, aside from using kernel interfaces. For the DPDK case, if there's a bifurcated driver, the kernel interfaces could be used, but this is definitely not a cross-vendor interface."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-18 13:08:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

right so in the general case we should not assume the presens of a biforcated driver. to my knowaldge that is only supported by mellanox.

looking at the i40e driver vf representor support is enabled as a runtime option on the pf via i40e pmd
https://doc.dpdk.org/guides/nics/i40e.html#runtime-config-options

in this configuration there will be no kernel netdev associated with the PF to use iproute2 to manage the VFs mac adress.

as jan pointed out the preferred xml generation form managing sriov interface in libvirt is to use the 
<interface type='hostdev'> element not <hostdev mode='subsystem' type='pci'>

when <interface type='hostdev'> is used libvirt will set the mac on teh vf but if can only work when the PF is bound to the kernel.

i would be open to having os-vif set the mac on vf in general rather then libvirt but in the case of this patch if we want to do that i want to ensure we can use a vendor neutral way that work with or without a biforcated driver. otherwise i woudl prefer to keep it in nova via libvirt until a vendor neutral way is developed in ovs-dpdk to manage this. i spend the las half hour or so looking that the ovs and dpdk documentation but so far i unfortunetly dont see a way to manage the mac via ovs but if you know of one that would be the ideal approch in the case of ovs-dpdk."}, {'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2019-06-18 18:41:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> right so in the general case we should not assume the presens of a
 > biforcated driver. to my knowaldge that is only supported by
 > mellanox.
 > 
 > looking at the i40e driver vf representor support is enabled as a
 > runtime option on the pf via i40e pmd
 > https://doc.dpdk.org/guides/nics/i40e.html#runtime-config-options
 > 
 > in this configuration there will be no kernel netdev associated
 > with the PF to use iproute2 to manage the VFs mac adress.
 > 
 > as jan pointed out the preferred xml generation form managing sriov
 > interface in libvirt is to use the
 > <interface type='hostdev'> element not <hostdev mode='subsystem'
 > type='pci'>
 > 
 > when <interface type='hostdev'> is used libvirt will set the mac on
 > teh vf but if can only work when the PF is bound to the kernel.
 > 
 > i would be open to having os-vif set the mac on vf in general
 > rather then libvirt but in the case of this patch if we want to do
 > that i want to ensure we can use a vendor neutral way that work
 > with or without a biforcated driver. otherwise i woudl prefer to
 > keep it in nova via libvirt until a vendor neutral way is developed
 > in ovs-dpdk to manage this. i spend the las half hour or so looking
 > that the ovs and dpdk documentation but so far i unfortunetly dont
 > see a way to manage the mac via ovs but if you know of one that
 > would be the ideal approch in the case of ovs-dpdk.
  
@Sean, so what I am saying is let do <hostdev mode='subsystem' type='pci'> in nova so we don't need to change nova in the future. (also it is not likely that the for none-beforcated driver libvirt will set the mac address.). I agree that there is not common way to set the mac for beforcated and none-beforcated and that sucks.
but maybe there will be in the future :).
So if we do <interface type='hostdev'> we may need to go back to   <hostdev mode='subsystem' when a common way of mac address will be resolved. (my comment assume that no one will do the change in libvirt)
Let me know what you think?"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-20 12:41:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My specific bikeshed opinion is to push all the uncertainty right into libvirt. Using interface type=hostdev is kind of the devil we know.

However, I can also see the value in doing the treating in an os-vif plugin. It's not my first choice, but it really is a matter of "taste". If we're doing it as an os-vif plugin I'd at least like some documentation or signoff on a spec: mostly the reason being that this would then be a "reference implementation" or reference spec where people could refer to, if they wanted to reimplement this in some other non-OpenStack system.

Summary: Doing this in libvirt interface-type-hostdev mode, means this patch is unnecessary, I'm pro that. I'm not against doing it using the untreated pci passthrough mode, BUT I can be easily bribed by a good spec / documentation.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-08 12:55:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I wrote down some random thoughts to sean on IRC. Please don't take these as anything but trying to look at the issue from a high-level perspective.

1. The MAC of the VF may be visible to the host after unplugging, depending on external factors. (rebind to netdev driver because of udev, libvirt or operator setup)
2. We also want to destroy information, leaving no chance that the next guest can somehow figure out the MAC of another tenant's VM.
3. I _think_ Linux is mostly "OK" with having multiple netdevs with the same MAC. I don't think it's good practice.
4. There are a number of places things can go wrong during plug/unplug. If the random MAC is guaranteed to not clash with the Neutron MAC space, we'd have a better safety guard.

However: https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/configuration/neutron.html#DEFAULT.base_mac

The Neutron MAC space is user configurable. I think sean's idea was to have the random MAC generated by the vendor in vendor space. That's going to be hugely finicky to do from os-vif's point of view.'}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:01:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:18:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I'd be grateful if someone could tell me what would happen in the following scenario, ignoring OpenStack and os-vif for now:

1. Consider br-test with the following interfaces:
1.1 PF pmd (10GBE port)
1.2 repr_for_vf1 (MAC ca:fe:--:01)
1.3 repr_for_vf2 (MAC ca:fe:--:02)

VF1 and VF2 are invisible to the host and are assigned to VM's VM1 and VM2 respectively.

2. The interface for repr_for_vf2 gets deleted, without resetting the MAC.

In this scenario, there are four packets to be considered:

1. from the wire hitting the PF addressed to MAC ca:fe:--:02
2. from VM1 with src MAC ca:fe:--:01 and dst MAC ca:fe:--:02
3. from VM2 with src MAC ca:fe:--:02 and dst MAC ca:fe:--:01
4. from VM2 with src MAC ca:fe:--:02 addressed to something on the wire.

If _any_ of these packets are forwarded, then setting the MAC to a random value will have a chance at a collision. It will likely be tiny, but will be painful to debug.

My suspicion is that the act of removing the repr interface would:

1. invalidate the existing rules that allow forwarding to and from the interface
2. install drops (or ignore packets) for all four cases."}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:42:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:45:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> I'd be grateful if someone could tell me what would happen in the
 > following scenario, ignoring OpenStack and os-vif for now:
 > 
 > 1. Consider br-test with the following interfaces:
 > 1.1 PF pmd (10GBE port)
 > 1.2 repr_for_vf1 (MAC ca:fe:--:01)
 > 1.3 repr_for_vf2 (MAC ca:fe:--:02)
 > 
 > VF1 and VF2 are invisible to the host and are assigned to VM's VM1
 > and VM2 respectively.
 > 
 > 2. The interface for repr_for_vf2 gets deleted, without resetting
 > the MAC.
 > 
 > In this scenario, there are four packets to be considered:
 > 
 > 1. from the wire hitting the PF addressed to MAC ca:fe:--:02

if this was a normal nic and you recived a packet form the wire it would not get queued to the PF it would be encured directly to the VF.

the hardware classifier in the nic would find a mac entry in the mac table and use that to select the vsi of the VF and it would be encued on the VF recive queue without ever being sent to the PF so it would never be seen by the PMD or the vswitch.

 > 2. from VM1 with src MAC ca:fe:--:01 and dst MAC ca:fe:--:02
 > 3. from VM2 with src MAC ca:fe:--:02 and dst MAC ca:fe:--:01
 > 4. from VM2 with src MAC ca:fe:--:02 addressed to something on the
 > wire.
 > 
 > If _any_ of these packets are forwarded, then setting the MAC to a
 > random value will have a chance at a collision. It will likely be
 > tiny, but will be painful to debug.
 > 
 > My suspicion is that the act of removing the repr interface would:
 > 
 > 1. invalidate the existing rules that allow forwarding to and from
 > the interface
 > 2. install drops (or ignore packets) for all four cases.

i would not expect drop rules to be installed in any of the aobove cases. if there is no represntor for a vf i would not expect any ovs configuration to be applied to the packets with the vf mask. i would only expect ovs to manage packet that were recived by the PF and in this case 1 it will not be recived by the pf.

in case 2 i would expet the packet to be TX onto the wire and hairpin at the tor if that is enabled. the reason for this is ovs will not have the dest interace attached to a bridge so it would lean the mac adress as assocated with the pf so it will encueue it on the PF tx queue and it will be transmitted onto the wire.

in case 3 i would expect the packet to be txd via the vf hit the cassifyer and be sent to the either the VF of vm 1 if there is a steady path flow or be sent to the pf for calssification if the flow had expired and then to vm 1.

and case 4 it should just go form vm2 directly onto the wire. nic will not have a local match entry for the something else but shoud lean it as assocaited with the uplink port.

its important to rememebr that form the point of view of a packet coming to and from a vf  the PF and the uplink to the phyical network ar not the same thing. the PF and VFs are all reperesented as VSIs(virtual station interface) attached to a logical switch with a upliknk port vsi which is the logica represnation of the phyical network or wire.

when a packet is recive by the nic it arrives on the uplink port and is decured by the parser/classifier to determin which RX queue to encure it on. in a standard nic if the vlan/mac of a VF matches the packet it will be encured onto the VF and never sent to the PF.

unless ovs-dpdk alters that i would not expect the behavior you describe.

when i have ran dpdk pmds on the pf and had vf bound to the kernel in the past you have been able to use them indepently of each other as normal interafce without dpdk chaning how the packet are deliverd to the vf."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:54:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

https://doc.dpdk.org/guides-19.02/nics/intel_vf.html#id2

provide a good diagram for what this looks like.
the l2 switch on there diagram is the embeded swithc/classifer that iw as referint too the this between the uplink port on one side the pfs and vfs on the other.

that page also shows how you can allocated viftual function while the PF is boudn to dpdk. the VF that are create this way can be use like any other vf and be boudn the the kernel driver as normal interfaces.

in fact we could even use them with vms while ovs-dpdk was running on the pf the issue is that libvirt cant set the mac on the vf because the pf is bound to dpdk so it works with qemu but not with libvirt/nova'}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Would you say this summary is accurate:
1. If the offloaded bridge emulates OVS perfectly, then this failure scenario is not expected to occur.
2. If OVS emulates a VEB NIC, then this failure scenario is possible.

Case 1. means that the offload hardware is very capable and OVS semantics map 1:1 from a software bridge to an offloaded bridge.

Case 2. is more complicated. In that case, the hardware might or might not be able to provide the necessary isolation.'}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-08 17:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

A general rule of thumb is : if no match in hardware then packet goes to the respective PF/VF representor.

[1] describes that DPDK VF representor ports behave the same as kernel VF representors when PF is in switchdev mode. so we should limit our discussion to NIC that behave according to that model.

if a rule is not offloaded it is expected to go to the OVS through the respective representor.
if the representor is not present (and no matching rule in HW ofc) then i _expect_ the packet to be dropped.

I will check internally about the expected behaviour when DPDK is used.'}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-08 17:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

forgot [1] :)

[1] https://doc.dpdk.org/guides-18.05/prog_guide/switch_representation.html#port-representors'}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-09 12:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

So under the assumption that the embedded switch is operating in
what is called switchdev mode as i mentioned in the previous comments
(and no legacy mac learning is performed in hardware),we would have the following
behaviour for the scenario @Jan Gutter mentioned above:

once the VF representor port is removed from OVS two things happen:
1. all rules for the corresponding port in the embedded switch are invalidated.
2. the respective DPDK VF port representor is "dangling" i.e from DPDK POV, any packet
   that hits the representor is ignored.

 >1. from the wire hitting the PF addressed to MAC ca:fe:--:02

as no matching rule in embedded switch, packed goes to br-test (through the uplink representor/PF representor) and acts
according to the rules set in OVS (drop/normal). if normal, arp will not be sent
to VF2 as its representor is not plugged to ovs.

 >2. from VM1 with src MAC ca:fe:--:01 and dst MAC ca:fe:--:02

no matching rules in embedded switch, packet will go to OVS through VF1 representor port
then same as above.
 
 >3. from VM2 with src MAC ca:fe:--:02 and dst MAC ca:fe:--:01

no rule for VF2 in embedded switch, packed goes to its respected representor and dropped.

 >4. from VM2 with src MAC ca:fe:--:02 addressed to something on the wire.
 
no rule for VF2 in embedded switch, packed goes to its respected representor and dropped.


Hardware that implements a hybrid of legacy and switchdev should have a clear separation
between embedded switch ports that are acting as switchdev and other that act in legacy mode.
(logically regard them as two different embedded switches IMO)'}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-09 12:06:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

apologies for the bad formatting above'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-09 17:33:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Code-Review

(1 comment)

ah great thanks for the link section 10.4 is exactuly what i wanted to review 

https://doc.dpdk.org/guides-18.05/prog_guide/switch_representation.html#initialization


so i am used to working with dpdk and sriov in what they refer to as basis sriov mode with unmanaged interconnects. when the pf is set to switchdev mode it works in controled interconect mode. 

the last bullet point after the diagram in section 10.4.2 is the important one "In this context, port index 3 can be thought as a representor for physical port 0."

so in swtichdev mode the pf becomes a proxy for the uplink port and recives all traffic unless it sets up flow to do otherwise.

section 10.4.3 https://doc.dpdk.org/guides-18.05/prog_guide/switch_representation.html#traffic-steering discribe the basic flows that i had expected to be in place by default. But based on the other information in swithc dev mode if you remove the representor from the bridge i can see that it woudl be correct to also isolate the interfaces. by removign the interconect/rules.

while it would not be a safe assumtion to make that all use of ovs dpdk with a pf and sriov woudl be in switchdev mode, in the context of the ovs plugin that is an assertion we can make.

or rather if you are using the os-vif ovs plugin to manage dpdk represntor port then we can assert that you must initallise the PF in switchdev mode.

if you want to use ovs dpdk and sriov concurrently without using swtichdev mode then that woudl still be possibel as in that case teh sriov port would be bound by the sriovnicagent ml2 driver and we would not use the ovs os-vif plugin to plug the port in that case.

removing -1 for now but i still have one suggestion inline.'}, {'account_id': 28714, 'date': '2020-01-12 12:29:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

as a hostdev and os-vif would be responsible for processing the
DPDK port and setting its MAC.

Closes-Bug: #1829734

as a hostdev and os-vif would be responsible for processing the

Change-Id: I5368c318cc0cfd7b5644d3da0dccbce7a48d6a85
Closes-Bug: #1829734
'}, {'created': '2019-12-24 15:42:56.000000000', 'message': '[Follow Up] OVS DPDK port representors support

as a hostdev and os-vif should pass the MAC to ovs as it would be
responsible for setting its MAC.

In case of DPDK representor port, Nova will pass through the VF PCI
as a hostdev and os-vif should pass the MAC to ovs as it would be
responsible for setting its MAC.
Moreover, update the MAC with a random generated one for the port
before deleting it

Change-Id: I5368c318cc0cfd7b5644d3da0dccbce7a48d6a85
Closes-Bug: #1829734

commit_message:
[Follow Up] OVS DPDK port representors support

Pass VF MAC address to ovs to set in case of netdev VIFHostDevice.

In case of DPDK representor port, Nova will pass through the VF PCI
as a hostdev and os-vif should pass the MAC to ovs as it would be
responsible for setting its MAC.
Moreover, when not using dpdk, libvirt does the mac cleanup,
since the VF is managed by libvirt, but when using DPDK,
libvirt does not manage the VF so we need to cleanup MAC address
in os-vif.

Change-Id: I5368c318cc0cfd7b5644d3da0dccbce7a48d6a85
Closes-Bug: #1829734

commit_message:
remotefs: remove invalid "external" arg on lock method

This is not implemented correctly (can't be used), and
has no users, so just remove it.

Change-Id: I923a9b36ba53d1367c2c49aeb26ada89c5e0e407

commit_message:
Revert "Do not use pip 10 or higher"

This reverts commit f99d1771ba1882dfbb69186212a197edae3ef02c.

Added workarounds that might want to get split into their own patch
before merging:

- Don't install python-psutil
- Don't run peakmem_tracker

Change-Id: If4fb16555e15082a4d97cffdf3cfa608a682997d

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-17 23:16:29.000000000', 'message': '[WIP][RFC][PoC] Fix for NDR testing race conditon

This is WIP and request for comments proof of concept PR.

The root cause seems to be upstream in the dragent. It may never
have been envisioned to run the agent by itself the way the charm does.

So that even if neutron-api completes its amqp relation first,
neutron-dynamic-routing can still see
oslo_messaging.exceptions.MessagingTimeout errors. Some opertion
must occur against neutron before dragent is truly ready. i.e. some post
deploy openstack command. So it is outside the purview of the charm.

This change adds the amqp relation to neutron-dynamic-routing late.
Post-deploy after networks have been configured.

Change-Id: I70ca12e77245ffcfc4aca5582f4bfac347ed6bed
Partial-Bug: #1841459
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/155

commit_message:
[WIP][RFC][PoC] Fix for NDR testing race conditon

This is WIP and request for comments proof of concept PR.

The root cause seems to be upstream in the dragent. It may never
have been envisioned to run the agent by itself the way the charm does.

So that even if neutron-api completes its amqp relation first,
neutron-dynamic-routing can still see
oslo_messaging.exceptions.MessagingTimeout errors. Some opertion
must occur against neutron before dragent is truly ready. i.e. some post
deploy openstack command. So it is outside the purview of the charm.

This change adds the amqp relation to neutron-dynamic-routing late.
Post-deploy after networks have been configured.

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/155
Change-Id: I70ca12e77245ffcfc4aca5582f4bfac347ed6bed
Partial-Bug: #1841459

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-20 15:24:15.000000000', 'message': "Improve error messaging around auth failures

Rather than just dumping the raw HTTPError exception, we should provide
some additional guidance for the end user in the specific case that it's
still returning 401 when we attempt to authenticate. Because we retry
authentication to reissue tokens, if the authentication ultimately fails
with 401 then it points to bad credentials or the container/registry is
not actually available. Some registries return 401 instead of a 404.

Change-Id: Ic8da92d98656bcea7db5701b44eeadc1d5c87198
Closes-Bug: #1860040
(cherry picked from commit d15d8df6ce4ab2329c1161676e2ceb8bc4467497)
"}]
commit_message:
Improve error messaging around auth failures

Rather than just dumping the raw HTTPError exception, we should provide
some additional guidance for the end user in the specific case that it's
still returning 401 when we attempt to authenticate. Because we retry
authentication to reissue tokens, if the authentication ultimately fails
with 401 then it points to bad credentials or the container/registry is
not actually available. Some registries return 401 instead of a 404.

Change-Id: Ic8da92d98656bcea7db5701b44eeadc1d5c87198
Closes-Bug: #1860040
(cherry picked from commit d15d8df6ce4ab2329c1161676e2ceb8bc4467497)

Derive network config fails

Derive network config fails for a role when using
any interface routes with list_concat_unique in network
configuration and no user inputs provided.

Change-Id: I26bb26411f22c34ead1b2bfb2a616ddf65f69489
Closes-Bug: #1856124
(cherry picked from commit 81e823c6222b580ca78f4cfa92008e08b9926e1e)
(cherry picked from commit 9e5bcae62c8bbcd952253a5611c49dd848a091d7)

commit_message:
Add Secret Consumer Controllers and their tests

This patch is part of a series to implement the Secret Consumers spec:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/barbican-specs/specs/train/secret-consumers.html

Fix _do_extra_dict_fields() in models.Secret to returns consumers.

Change-Id: I3637cd174ee3d7b31b148c3b86f7c8e0ab4472c9
Signed-off-by: Moises Guimaraes de Medeiros <moguimar@redhat.com>

These systems use LIO via python-rtslib, and targetcli depends

commit_message:
DIB: replace targetcli with target-restore on RHEL/CentOS 8

These systems use LIO via python-rtslib, and targetcli depends
on libX11 and other GUI packages. The target-restore package
(coming from python-rtslib) is enough to create the necessary
directories (e.g. /etc/target).

Change-Id: Ide0d23d3834c52edcbc569c05ce95ba78e1bf73d

commit_message:
Fix entry paths for cleaning and deployment

The explicit removal of agent_url to prevent conflicts...
turned out to be another issue with fast_track.

Change-Id: Ibd93bb255d5664a431f9be9c39c9fc8c67ff7608
Story: 2007080
Task: 37991
(cherry picked from commit 0a94391e34b7d1caa4e99c81ddf4f651f457795e)

commit_message:
py3: Fix formpost unicode filename issues

Previously, we took the native string filename attribute and put it
directly in the (WSGI string) PATH_INFO field. Now, we convert it to
a WSGI string first.

Change-Id: I30e3beb8707b88c36bd3cdc7a0887d069e943ba6
Closes-Bug: #1858259

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-21 09:57:40.000000000', 'message': "Fix set -o pipefail failures on non RHEL distros

Distros like debian and ubuntu, are using dash as default shell, who
doesn't have set -o pipefail, however, these distros also have bash
installed, and can be used.
According https://github.com/ansible/ansible-lint/issues/497 the way to
fix it right now, is to use /bin/bash in the shell command that requires
the set -o pipefail. This is already done in other components like
ceph-ansible for example, and would allow us to use collect-logs in
other distros. This is also required to have collect-logs running in OSA
jobs, since they test different distros.

Change-Id: If3c3b9275ce3df574511a18e3455741069bb6d26
"}]
commit_message:
Fix set -o pipefail failures on non RHEL distros

Distros like debian and ubuntu, are using dash as default shell, who
doesn't have set -o pipefail, however, these distros also have bash
installed, and can be used.
According https://github.com/ansible/ansible-lint/issues/497 the way to
fix it right now, is to use /bin/bash in the shell command that requires
the set -o pipefail. This is already done in other components like
ceph-ansible for example, and would allow us to use collect-logs in
other distros. This is also required to have collect-logs running in OSA
jobs, since they test different distros.

Change-Id: If3c3b9275ce3df574511a18e3455741069bb6d26

commit_message:
add X.509 certificate check plugin for monasca-agent

We need this in order to monitor the internal TLS certificates. Since
backporting feature to stable/rocky is not feasible, the next option is
to patch RPM.

Change-Id: I3b1dc233ab4df996711fa8ee799d0c7eedbf4790

can we please use "collections: openstack.cloud" as a play attribute, so that module names are not so terrible'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-01-21 09:10:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

@Artem I tried it in the beginning, but it didn't work - for some reason it used modules from ansible code, not from collections. I suggest to investigate it in followup patches."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2020-01-21 09:33:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

While I'd prefer to see us share the job and playbooks with the SDK, it's more important at this stage to get some sort of functional test in to unblock new patches coming in for functional changes."}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-01-21 09:44:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Jesse, job will run on sdk: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/703565/'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-01-21 13:35:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Artem, if using "collections: ..." it will take modules from core, not from collection if they have the same name, so no choice - must use full path.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2020-01-21 14:51:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2020-01-21 15:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> @Artem, if using "collections: ..." it will take modules from core,
 > not from collection if they have the same name, so no choice - must
 > use full path.

A "nice" thing we should report back to Ansible. This is indeed wrong. At least we will have option to rename this once modules are removed in core.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-01-21 16:15:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Yeah, I reported this to Ansible folks, they confirmed it's a bug."}]

commit_message:
Configure keystone_authtoken/service_token_roles

This patch introduces a new hieradata to configure service_token_roles
in keystone authtoken middleware configuration, so that we can use
a customized role for user who uses service token feature.

Change-Id: Iad16376047628bd16470dd4fd17fd260b927aa6c

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-17 20:29:25.000000000', 'message': "Exclude all device_ids that belong to Neutron DHCP Agent

It looks like sometimes, the device_id for ports created
by Neutron DHCP Agent can be in the form of:

- dhcp-$hostuuid-$networkid
- 'reserved_dhcp_port' (DEVICE_ID_RESERVED_DHCP_PORT)

Current code is only taking the first form into account when
skipping Neutron DHCP Agent ports. This patch is changing it
to include both forms.

Closes-Bug: #1848521
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)
"}]
commit_message:
Exclude all device_ids that belong to Neutron DHCP Agent

It looks like sometimes, the device_id for ports created
by Neutron DHCP Agent can be in the form of:

- dhcp-$hostuuid-$networkid
- 'reserved_dhcp_port' (DEVICE_ID_RESERVED_DHCP_PORT)

Current code is only taking the first form into account when
skipping Neutron DHCP Agent ports. This patch is changing it
to include both forms.

Closes-Bug: #1848521
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ifbfc551ac68dcc5d3d39a155f7642f2f2d9272c4
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15bf8f265b14c3a1e2c89a17a77cee69cad22b9d)

commit_message:
Programatically generate ssh hosts lines

This change will ensure that the ssh hosts lines we create are
programatically generated. This will ensure we're not running
into errors caused by missing or bad facts or generating lines
that do not make sense caused by bad string slicing or one off
jinja errors.

Related-Bug: #1837644
Related-Bug: #1855149
Closes-Bug: #1856893
Change-Id: I3696238b26d8567bc3145a22b2b9ec944cb14d13
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-10 12:55:29.000000000', 'message': 'Fix revision number race condition with attaching router interfaces

There's a special case in the update_port_precommit() method to handle
the case where an existing port is being added to a router. The method
will try to create an entry in the ovn_revision_numbers table but, if
that entry is already present a DBDuplicateEntry exception will be
raised and the whole update method will fail.

The update_port_precommit() is the only method at present that have this
special handler, for all other resources creating a new record in the
ovn_revision_numbers table happens at the create_*_precommit() methods
(this include create_port_precommit() as well).

This patch is fixing the problem by adding a new parameter to the
reate_initial_revision() method called "may_exist". When set to True the
code will not raise an DBDuplicateEntry if the record already exists. By
default this method is False.

Closes-Bug: #1800875
Change-Id: Iddd89725e617b22c35e30ae7f20a7f87de296cdb
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit b5642d93a6c0ce0141fb5f61a3d853b026b7b67d)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix revision number race condition with attaching router interfaces

There's a special case in the update_port_precommit() method to handle
the case where an existing port is being added to a router. The method
will try to create an entry in the ovn_revision_numbers table but, if
that entry is already present a DBDuplicateEntry exception will be
raised and the whole update method will fail.

The update_port_precommit() is the only method at present that have this
special handler, for all other resources creating a new record in the
ovn_revision_numbers table happens at the create_*_precommit() methods
(this include create_port_precommit() as well).

This patch is fixing the problem by adding a new parameter to the
reate_initial_revision() method called "may_exist". When set to True the
code will not raise an DBDuplicateEntry if the record already exists. By
default this method is False.

Closes-Bug: #1800875
Change-Id: Iddd89725e617b22c35e30ae7f20a7f87de296cdb
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit b5642d93a6c0ce0141fb5f61a3d853b026b7b67d)
